Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I know she and Dad expect me to check in, to share how things are going, to keep that connection alive. I promised I’d be better about it, especially since I moved out. But tonight, my district is hosting a live online candidate forum—something I’ve been waiting for all week. As a citizen, I feel a responsibility to stay informed, to listen, to maybe even submit a question. The forum is only streaming now, and I know how important it is to participate, to have a voice in my community. My phone buzzes again, another gentle nudge from home. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in—my parents’ hope for a call, my own sense of duty to civic life. I sit on the edge of my bed, torn, the expectations pulling me in opposite directions, my heart racing as I try to decide which role to honor first.
